It doesn't make for a sac because the e pawn still blocks the Q, basically.
The normal h5 would be answered by h3, but black went for the hiper-aggressive choice, that is not the best one.
Now my N is safe, and ready to go g6 if black dares to move his h pawn.
He did, solidifying his outpost in g4, but "giving" me g6 in the process, which is an almost fatal mistake.
Despite its weird position, the Q is aiming to g6, with lethal effect on black's position. Moreover, it prevents f5 by black.

Well, that's funny and tricky. Of course black had Rh6, preventing Qg6+, and standing for Ng6 - not so dangerous. But this - a "bad" move, makes me think a lot: I can easily find myself overrisking and falling into blunders...
Developing - threatening d5, thinking in a future Nb5. Not a good plan, but Ng6 seemed pretty pointless, now. It was not, because after Rh6, Nf4 would have been very interesting, pressing e6.
Covering f5, too. Too bad.
Let's try to open the position! My superior developement will then prevail.
Hard decision: Q or R to take on e4?
Well, Nc5+, BxN, dxB+, etc, is the worst thing that can happen to me... so this can't be bad.
I expected the exchange, regretting I didn't take before the Ng6 - NxBf8 - train, which would have left me with good control of black's squares from g3 - e5...
